docs.abstract: An interview with the 35th-richest person in the world, who is funding efforts on immigration, education and independent media.
docs.snippet: An interview with the 35th-richest person in the world, who is funding efforts on immigration, education and independent media.
docs.lead_paragraph: Before I could interview Laurene Powell Jobs, she wanted to interview me.

headline.main: Laurene Powell Jobs Is Putting Her Own Dent in the Universe
headline.print_headline: Putting Her Own Dent in the Universe

docs.abstract: Once a generation, Hollywood experiences a seismic shift. It is happening again.
docs.snippet: Once a generation, Hollywood experiences a seismic shift. It is happening again.
docs.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Every three decades, or roughly once a generation, Hollywood experiences a seismic shift. The transition from silent films to talkies in the 1920s. The rise of broadcast television in the 1950s. The raucous “I Want My MTV” cable boom of the 1980s.

headline.main: The Streaming Era Has Finally Arrived. Everything Is About to Change.
headline.print_headline: The Streaming Era Has Finally Arrived.  Everything Is About to Change.

docs.abstract: A new special section — inside a special section, inside the Sunday newspaper — explores the future of streaming entertainment.
docs.snippet: A new special section — inside a special section, inside the Sunday newspaper — explores the future of streaming entertainment.
docs.lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline.main: How We Created a ‘Turducken’ of Media News

docs.abstract: The request set up a collision between law enforcement and big technology firms in the latest battle over privacy and security.
docs.snippet: The request set up a collision between law enforcement and big technology firms in the latest battle over privacy and security.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr declared on Monday that a deadly shooting last month at a naval air station in Pensacola, Fla., was an act of terrorism, and he asked Apple in an unusually high-profile request to provide access to two phones used by the gunman.

headline.main: Barr Asks Apple to Unlock Pensacola Killer’s Phones, Setting Up Clash
headline.print_headline: Clash Looming In Bid to Open Killer’s iPhones

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

docs.abstract: The proposal could save costs and thousands of tons of electronic waste, advocates say, but previous measures have fizzled.
docs.snippet: The proposal could save costs and thousands of tons of electronic waste, advocates say, but previous measures have fizzled.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The European Union wants to make it easier to charge your cellphone and other devices.

headline.main: A Common Charger for All Phones? The E.U. Is on the Case
headline.print_headline: E.U. Keeps Up Its Push For Common Chargers, Citing E-Waste ‘Ocean’

docs.abstract: Plus, Apple takes on Trump in a standoff over iPhone privacy.
docs.snippet: Plus, Apple takes on Trump in a standoff over iPhone privacy.
docs.lead_paragraph: In a week dominated by impeachment headlines, big money kept moving. The stock market hummed along, Google hit the $1 trillion valuation mark and banks reported fat quarterly earnings. Next, the who’s who of global politics and finance will fly to the snow-capped ski town of Davos, Switzerland, for the World Economic Forum. To catch up and prep for the week ahead, read on.

headline.main: The Week in Business: Hot Topic at Davos

docs.abstract: A surprise announcement added to concerns about the ability of American tech giants to navigate an increasingly uncertain economy and a trade war with China.
docs.snippet: A surprise announcement added to concerns about the ability of American tech giants to navigate an increasingly uncertain economy and a trade war with China.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple reduced its revenue expectations for the first time in 16 years on Wednesday because of poor iPhone sales in China, an unexpected development that underscored the slowing of China’s economy and raised fears of further turmoil in global markets.

headline.main: Apple Cuts Revenue Forecast Because of Slow iPhone Sales in China
headline.print_headline: China’s Slump Leads to Drop In Apple Sales

byline.original: By Jack Nicas and Keith Bradsher

docs.abstract: The iPhone maker, which depends on both factories and consumers in China, could be a bellwether for other big tech companies.
docs.snippet: The iPhone maker, which depends on both factories and consumers in China, could be a bellwether for other big tech companies.
docs.lead_paragraph: Hello, New York Times tech readers. I’m Nellie Bowles, the tech and culture reporter, here now with the roundup of the news.

headline.main: The Week in Tech: Coronavirus Hits Apple’s Financial Forecast

docs.abstract: The fine comes as the iPhone maker deals with the impact of the coronavirus pandemic.
docs.snippet: The fine comes as the iPhone maker deals with the impact of the coronavirus pandemic.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — France’s antitrust regulator on Monday fined Apple 1.1 billion euros, or $1.2 billion, putting more pressure on the company as it grapples with the coronavirus outbreak that has threatened its supply chains and closed its retail stores.

headline.main: France Fines Apple $1.2 Billion for Antitrust Issues

docs.abstract: The tech giant, which will keep its stores in the China region open, becomes one of the first retailers to shut its doors in an effort to halt the spread of the coronavirus.
docs.snippet: The tech giant, which will keep its stores in the China region open, becomes one of the first retailers to shut its doors in an effort to halt the spread of the coronavirus.
docs.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Apple said it would close most of its retail stores outside mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan, becoming one of the first companies to take such a drastic measure to fight the coronavirus outbreak.

headline.main: Apple Closes Most of Its Stores for 2 Weeks
